reviewText:
This game is great.  A little different, but different is definitely good.  It reminds me of when I was younger and get a new game, like Darklands, Dark Sun, Wiz 7, or Realms of Arkania, and I had to take my time and figure out the rules and not know what was going to happen.  We have kind of been indoctrinated now to know our hands will be held and we can just click through everything or not worry about the character development system because gimping your character is impossible and combat is mindless.  This game gives me that feeling I had when I was younger and installed a new crpg and I knew it was meaty and I had to think and plan and take my time to figure things out.

Graphics are not the best, but the gameplay and mechanics more than make up for it.

RtwP combat almost always sucks, but isn't too bad in this game.  I think it is done a lot better than Pillars of Eternity and the IE games at least.

I give it an 8/10 since it doesn't have TB combat.

I highly recommend this game to anyone who likes real crpgs in general; anyone who liked the Infinity Engine games or NWN; or, for more recent examples, anyone who liked Pillars of Eternity, D:OS, M&MX, or WL2.


EDIT:  Just some more information on the game.  It has old school puzzles, such as from the original Quest for Glory 1 and 2 (where you had to type all commands), where you have an object in game that you know does something, but you have no idea how to go about getting it to do what it was made to do.  For instance, (slight spoiler ahead) there is a ring of purple flowers.  If you use your woodlore skill on it you find that a fairy is trapped inside by magic.  There is a linguistic system where you type a prefix, power word, and the object of the spell.  This system may have an effect on it, or not.  Or maybe you need two skill points in linguistics?  Who knows?  Not me.  It could be something completely different.  I would have said yesterday I love things like this where you have to think and put your brain against the game, but I'm finding I'm a lot more impatient than I was when I first played QfG and this game is making me feel stupid.  And there are no walkthroughs.  I do think this is a great aspect of the game, but I kind think it is also kind of infuriating.  I'm kind of obsessive and I am having a real hard time leaving the first outside area because there are two things I haven't been able to figure out.

If I were normal I would just add some notes in the jounral and come back later, but I'm not, and after work I plan on showing these puzzles who is boss.  Sadly, there is a good chance I'm not the boss.   though.

These days, even mere mortals are more than awesome enough to do everything in spectacular fashion. Take Skyrim for example, everybody needs your help, you always have the capabilities to solve every task, and within hours you become strong enough to singlehandedly kill dragons. Along with this unparalleled power, players enjoyed countless luxuries, such as dozens of quest indicators, as well as arrows that point out exactly where to go and who to talk to. Serpent in the Staglands takes an approach that gamers have either long forgotten, or never even knew existed.

You are the all-powerful Moon Lord, or were I should say. Someone or something has trapped you in the mortal realm. When you start off, all you're given are some directions, papers identifying you as a merchant, and the assistance of a few allies. Before long, you will face your first great adversary, a wolf. Starting off in this game reminds me of the first Baldur's Gate. In that RPG, you started off at level 1, and even the weakest creatures led to life or death struggles. In the beginning of my adventure, I summoned an ethereal ally, and requested the help of a couple of others. Our party of four was no match for a few wolves.

We all need a little help sometimes, but this game won't provide any. Aside from the always handy ability to save anywhere , you're on your own. Actually, I take that back. You're also given a journal so you can jot down any and all notes. Yes, if you come across a quest, you should write it down along with all pertinent information, because you might forget. Another aspect to keep in mind is that alongside combat and magic skills, there are also certain talents you should be training. With up to five party members, there is room to specialize, so you'll want someone that can speak to nobles, another that will brew potions, the one guy who can understand old texts, and so on. As you explore the Staglands, you'll meet others willing to join your cause". It's worth swapping allies around

What a beautifully crafted game, I truly regret I didn't hear of this when it was on Kickstarter.

So, Serpent in the Staglands is a CRPG made by 2 people, a couple, who are pretty amazing at what they do. One makes art that is in the same style of old 90s games aesthetically, and the other creates the assets/rules/codes like some wizard determined to bring out a really great game.

For the game itself; it is truly a throwback to the old immersive RPG's from the 90s, no quest markers, nothing to hold your hand and only you and your characters actual knowledge of what is around you. It treats you like a normal human, one with normal situational comprehension, deduction, forethought and reasoning.

Writers for characters in videogame has most of the time complained that romances is the last thing they write, as it mostly reminds them of bad writing in literature. And it mostly is since it adds nothing to the depth of the character. You will see none of it in Serpent in the Staglands since it tries, like many non-romancable RPG's of the time - to be a respectable game.

The game has a classless system where you decide for yourself what you want your character to use or become, on its own it opens up many unique opportunities; to roleplay as someone else if that is your thing; since the game has a ton of skills to choose from. (I myself made a Castlevania-esque inspired vampire slayer - whip and all kinds of thrown stuff and holy magic). Like many old games it relies on the player to -be- their character, no logs to backtrack quest progress, no mystical magical map of the whole world that pinpoints your exact position or holding your hand towards your next" location. It wants you to explore the world on your own

reviewText:
Firstly, everything that you've read about this games opacity and difficulty is true. I never played Darklands, it's 'spiritual predecessor', but just about every other 16bit classic I have - including Ultima VII again, only recently.

I liked: The setting, character and the writing of the game. At times knowing or literate or funny, and at others merely enjoyably silly. It felt like the strongest part of the game. I like the 'feel' of the low magic (even if it's less exciting to play, and it is.) The skills system is clever and would probably reward more play than I'm prepared to put into this game.

So what did I bounce off, given that list of positives? This game still feels very much like an alpha build, rushed to publishers demands, and incomplete. The feedback in the world is at times non-existent. I spent HOURS trying to figure out where a particular well was(a quest was pointing me at it.) in the first town. No text cues at all, you're meant to see a tiny altered graphic on the screen, and it clearly isn't MEANT to be obscure. Just one example, but that felt typical of the play experience.
The load times are just horrendous, and indicative of ineffecient coding and design - oh, and you'll be seeing the gratingly amateurish death and load screens a lot, almost as much as you'll be playing. This is as the combat is brutal and unforgiving, unknowingly encounter enemies for the first time and die. Again and again and again, till you start learning what the games systems.
And BUGS. BUGS everywhere! sometimes game stopping. You can read about them all elsewhere.

I find that now I just don't care enough, certainly not enough to have paid £15 to be a beta tester on a game. I am already sick of the game's flaws.

There's much to admire about this game and its creation, but unfortunately not as much to enjoy.

reviewText:
A friendly reminder that taking on a pack of wolves with a kitchen knife, or single point in a first level spell is a bad idea.

Serpent in the Staglands is a modern 'old-school' style crpg in both look and feel. Gone are the arrows of patronization, the quest log, the terrible bland puzzles that a brain dead toddler could figure out, and in is a true return to form of open world crpgs bursting at the seams with love and attention to detail. For a game made by a team of two people, it is one of the gaming masterworks of this decade in my eyes.

The Bad:
1. At the time of playing, many small errors in displayed item statistics, skill descriptions, and other details were littered here and there. However, the new patches seem to be ironing out all of these typos and issues.

2. Lack of sound variation is something that detracts from immersion in combat. There are painfully few sound effects for all the various spells and weapons. Two spells that have wildly different effects generally ought to have wildly different sounds, if sound is to be an integral feature to add to them.

3. For those that love magic, know that it will take many points of investment to be an effective full time mage. It is simply part of the flavor of the setting, not necessarily a mark against the game, but it could put off those that chose this path for their first playthrough.

4. The technical - loading times and video resolution - The loading times were very slow when I played through the game, making every death even more painful. Just because I want a crpg like those released in the late 90's doesn't mean I want a resolution like what they had. The game is beautiful but the constant close up feeling can wear on the senses after a while, at least for me.

The Good:
1. The story is a simple, yet strong premise. You are a god somehow locked into the mortal coil possessing a flesh and blood avatar. If you die in your current form you will be swept out of existence like any other mortal. Your quest is to get home, while finding out who put you into this situation and exacting your vengeance if you wish.

2. Incredibly sculpted world with a smorgasbord of lore that you can dig out with relatively little effort. The setting is dark, internally realistic, and all settlements and people are logically and lovingly placed. On many items, from the mundane to incredible artifacts, are paragraphs of flavor text to become immersed in.

3. Almost all the quests are unique, memorable, can be done at any time, and usually have a myriad of solutions. Some solutions can have unforeseen consequences that tie into the world much more intricately than a simple bumbleton reputation +5"

Also gone is the arrow of patronization

reviewText:
Serpent in the Staglands is an isometric RPG in the vein of classic party-based Infinity Engine titles such as Baldur's Gate, coupled with an enthralling pixelated aesthetic. The execution of the story reminds me of Fallout 1. You're thrown into the world with nothing but a small idea of where to go, the rest is up to you.

I've always had a soft spot for RPGs such as Morrowind and Albion that take place in unique, weird and mysterious settings. Something that takes a leap away from the more established Tolkienesque/D&D derivative worlds with all the same tropes appearing from title to title.

Serpent in the Staglands is one of these more unique titles, set in the world of Vol, inspired by late bronze age Transylvania. Giant lichen and moss cover the landscape. It has a certain frontier feeling to it, with conflicts between the settlers, the natives and the environment itself. The game is filled with surprisingly detailed lore, from history to politics. Even the item descriptions are interesting to read through, given how alien the world of Vol is.

When I first started the game, I did the mistake of not reading the manual and starting with just one avatar. The combat is absolutely brutal even with a full party, so I ended up restarting the game with a full party of five people after 3-4 hours of gameplay. Magic is interesting, spells can be cast indefinately since there is no memorization or mana, but they take some time to prepare instead and can be interrupted by enemies. As such, mages seem to be much better suited to support roles. Leveling pace reminds me of the original Baldur's Gate. Your characters are utter weaklings in the beginning, but just getting from level 1 to 2 almost doubles your combat prowess. Be prepared to pick your fights early on.

The game has no automatic quest logging, so you have to write your own log entries instead in order to keep track of the quests you were given.

I don't mind the unforgiving combat, but frequent dying combined with excruciating loading times is frustrating. Almost every combat situation has a possibility of going completely awry, forcing you to reload and go through the loading screen that can take half a minute. It breaks the pacing of the game and gets annoying very quickly.

The user interface was a bit confusing at the beginning, but you get used to it quickly. My grievances are with the problems brought by the retro aesthetic, for example save game names can have only 16 characters at max, which makes it hard making up descriptive names for saves while still staying under the character limit. The same problem persists when writing notes in the journal, you can't really do much with only about 200 characters. Granted, you could just write that stuff on paper, but since the writable journal is a feature in the game, it feels a bit lazy argument.

I'd still wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone who feels hungry for an old-school RPG experience in a unique, different setting. Serpent in the Staglands is a beautiful game with a lot to offer, but it suffers from broken pacing caused by long loading times.

reviewText:
I love the art, but would it really hurt to explain how things work in the game?  I get that it's supposed to be a hard game, but why does it have to be so difficult to figure out how to play the game?  The interface feels very unintuitive for a CRPG with very little in the way of useful information presented to you.  To add to this, there's not much in-game help to explain what you're doing so you kinda have to fumble around and likely die or completely restart several times before you figure out what's going on.

There's supposed to be in game tool-tips (as seen in the options menu) but unless I'm doing something wrong, they never actually pop up on anything useful.  I don't know if that's a bug or not, but it's really frustrating having to open up my spell book every time I want to read what a certain quick cast spell does.  For that matter, I still don't know what that small bar of quick skills do.  I feel like if I knew these things I wouldn't be dying so much.  When any character falls in battle, they're permanently dead.  If the game were a little more intuitive I could welcome such an unforgiving difficulty, but as it stands, it's just cumbersome having to constantly save and reload.

One of the more baffling things in this game are mages.  For the life of me I can't figure out why anyone would cast spells in combat.  It feels incredibly clunky to try to cast anything in battle due to the awkwardly long cast time and how seemingly useless most of the spells are.  The only spell I've gotten any use out of is the healing spell, but it takes so long to cast in battle that your target is likely dead before it even goes off.  Again, I might be completely wrong and mages might be absolutely game breaking, but this game does such a poor job of introducing their playstyle, that I feel completely gimped using one.  It's kind of a shame because I typically love using mages in CRPGs.

Often as I was playing I wasn't sure if what I was encountering in the game was a bug, a design decision, or just something that wasn't properly explained.  For example, in my first playthrough before my party died, there were no NPCs on the screen.  Once I reloaded my game, all of a sudden the area I was in was filled with NPCs, one of them I could recruit into my party and he actually had real equipment, not just kitchen knives like the rest of my people had.  It felt odd to me that the party members I created felt so worthless the instant I recruited someone who came equipped with a real weapon.

Another random gripe I have is that the mouse scrolling in the game does not work very well with multiple monitors.  I have to use the arrow keys to pan the camera around since my cursor would go off screen anytime I tried to look around the area.  Also often times in battle when I would tell my characters to move somewhere they would get stuck on the most minor of obstacles even though there were plenty of free paths available to them.  I've played a lot of CRPGs, but none of them have been as frustrating to get the hang of as this one.

EDIT: I'm seeing a lot of comments about my gripe that scrolling doesn't work very well with multiple monitors.  I guess I'll clarify what I meant because I wasn't asking for multi-monitor support, I was asking for full screen mode to lock the cursor inside the borders of your active screen.  In most CRPGs, when you set the game to full screen mode, you can move your cursor to the edge of the screen and this will pan the camera in the direction of the edge you're touching.  In this game, full screen mode doesn't lock your cursor within the confines of the game, so when you have multiple monitors and try to scroll using your mouse, your cursor leaves the screen entirely and stops being registered.  From a development perspective, I don't imagine this would be a difficult fix to implement, but as it stands, you pretty much have to use the arrow keys to pan the camera around which puts your left hand at an awkward position for pausing, quick saving, and opening your spell book.

reviewText: This is my first RTwP CRPG and I'm honestly loving the hell out of it. The setting is inspired, and the sound design combines with the aesthetics in really pleasing ways to create this moody, dark experience that's nothing like anything that I've experienced in the best way. The world and the lore are really easy for me to get lost in, and keeping your own journal isn't as hard as it sounds and is one of the most immersive mechanics I've ever seen in a video game. The magic system is very reminiscent of the Eastern European fairytales that it so heavily draws from, and things like the Aptitudes' secondary effects (Woodwise allowing you to talk to animals, which leads to quest threads and other goodies). I love the feel of this game, and I even have come to love how quicksave-quickloady the combat tends to get, although that's not for everyone. It's kinda cool that you're always just a roll of the dice away from a bad situation, it's keeping me on my toes. I've definitely had to approach this  more slowly and with a hell of a lot more patience than I usually have for games, but it's paid dividends in immersion and potentially replayability. I've had a hell of an experience so far, and it's so damn different than everything else that I've been playing that I'd say, yeah, play it. Play the hell out of it, soak it up. Whether or not you like it and take to it is secondary to the experience of playing this game the way the creators of it clearly intended; with an open mind, and a hunger for a kind of adventure that not much else will get you. Also, play it having read the manual. :P

reviewText:
Serpent in the Staglands... I played through it even though I wasn't sure if I really would at the beginning.

+ I'm not big fan of all these Pixel Artists nowadays but if the game's god I don't mind. Serpent in the Staglands does it pretty good, the Art style doesn't annoy and it's animations are good.

+ Music was a little repetitive but the pieces themselves were excellent.

+ Story was good. Especially the main plot. You can explore the whole world right at the beginning and by far the best part is that lots of things you do on your journey participate on the main plot. So you don't feel like abandoning your original mission with stupid side quests, it just fits!

- Combat. I LOVE old school games. However I don't see the need for dice-calculated damage anymore. D&D had its own rules but a pure videogame ruleset should really manage differenty. Also a lot of the spells felt too similar and some of the others are just outright criminally op. The grade 3 Teleport-spell was the easy way to destroy everything at the end of the game. set it up, watch enemies loop themselves and meanwhile have your archer and your mage with Arcane Attack shoot down everything. Could have been countered by setting up less melee-only enemies.

- Puzzles. I just personally hate puzzles. Riddles? Totally! But definitly not puzzles where you have to travel half across the map to colect details you might have missed without even knowing IF there are any details you could have missed... Better put in more dialogues, they were ALL well executed! (+)


All in all I would recommend the game. For the low price it demands you get quite a lot of fun imo!

reviewText:
I was quite intrigued by this title. The promise of a flexible narrative and properly immersive RPG gameplay is something that will draw in quite a few players. However, I think the developers are going to find that large numbers of players never reach this element, if it does exist, due to introductions like the one I experienced. I reproduce my experience so that the designers can be aware of these stumbling blocks and perhaps address them.

The very beginning started out promisingly enough, with some unannounced figure querying me about my past as a god. I like this, I feel like I'm setting out some basic facts, imposing my personality on the game world. The slightly choppy graphics are no issue here, as I feel like it's being carried off with a retro style. I'm enthusiastic about crafting a character and seeing an introduction.

We hit the game world, and my brow furrows a bit. The text here is reading as fairly stilted, rather unpolished for so early and critical a scene. I am jarred by a typo, a grammatical error or two.

We're also being annoyingly scripted. I have almost no conversational options, my responses to information being deposited on me by this priest fellow are all pre-ordained. Where was that sense of imposing my personality from before? Perhaps I am a dread and vengeful god, who will truck none of this familiarity, leaving the priest to stutter out his apologies and plead with me to see reason? Perhaps I am a stoic creature, who tolerates a babbling priest with little more than a raised eyebrow and a knowing smile?

With a thin veil cast over it by the conversation, I come to the character creation screen. It's mildly confusing, but clicking around gets me a sense of it. Noting with some annoyance that the font size to container size ratio was bloating text into a long, thin arrangement I had to scroll up and down, I start studiously reading the lore on the various races and sub-races or classes (I was not sure which, and indeed was not sure that these boxes represented choices rather than a list of attributes until after the first character was completed).

Again, I find myself annoyed by some weak writing -- technically speaking, that is, I wouldn't complain about info-dumps in racial background text. My expectations are sinking. While I was hoping for effectively minimal, I would have settled for poor graphics, but what I expected in return was a rich and well-polished lore, well presented in an interface which is freed from the need to trace rays of starlight as they glimmer on the dewdrops of the gardens. What I seem to be getting is neither style nor substance.

Forging on, I design my avatar. I think about it carefully, testing the various races. I settle on a follower of the god I listed as my ally in the introduction, reasoning that it would be a sane choice for a temporarily mortal deity. I squint at the head of my avatar as I alter the options, trying to discern the features I am choosing.  I decide I'm done.

The priest asks me if I want to create a companion. I'll be able to hire mercenaries if I don't.

Perhaps this is due to a different gaming background, but I took that as a fantastic slap in the face. What, I'm being asked to create my entire adventuring party here, in this room, before I have seen anything of this world? Before I have any sense of what skills are valuable? Are mercenaries going to be my only other companions? Will I not pick up chance aquaintances, actual characters scattered around this world? Is the team never going to grow or shrink, barring my own calculations about mercenary hire? As it turns out, there are additional companions, though at least initially it would seem that gathering them is as simple as telling them to come with you.

There's not even any dressing on it. I am not being given the choice of concentrating my trapped essence into one form or multiple, balancing bonus skill points against the size of my party -- I can create one person, or what seems to be up to eight of identical strength (I did not in fact test the upper bound, I got bored of playing with the options at the fourth character).  This cheapens things quite considerably.

The priest now informs me of some people I could take with me. I feel uncomfortably aware that he is talking to a player rather than his deity. Perhaps it is my memory at fault, but I cannot, after this time in the character creation screen, recall what it was that he was advising me to do about my trapped-as-a-mortal issue. I could presumably find it in the backscroll, but I decide instead to explore my environment and the game's controls.

Wandering south, I summarily recruit someone to my party, finding no joy in it, as he is virtually indistinguishable from the characters I have so cheaply created. I find the journal system, and note with some pleasure that it operates as a create-your-own-notes system. I spend a few minutes creating an in-universe note about the trapped-as-a-mortal problem. Despite the ongoing problems with the relative sizes of the text and the textboxes, this simple setup is one of the most pleasing features so far, and reminds me why I wanted to play the game.

Spirits buoyed, I walk around the main hall clicking on things. I note with some irritation that it's occasionally taking a few tries for the click event to register properly. I find a book which I can bleed on, and presume that that will somehow be important later. I could swear that the book is titled 'I hate this ♥♥♥♥ing thing' or something like that.  The priest offers no explanation, nor recognition that I have found a strange item in his domain, he just tells me to go to the garden.

I wander into the library and peruse the shelves. I pick up a couple of items, speak briefly to some hovering NPCs who don't seem to have much to say. Here is where it goes wrong. I walk into the kitchen and decide to raid the cupboard. Clicking on it, the game produces a message in its sidebar about how this belongs to someone else. My attention momentarily distracted from the screen, I missed this message, and clicked again, thinking it was another instance of non-firing click events. I open the cupboards and am immediately branded an enemy of my own temple. Acolytes rush in to pummel my party with their fists. I stare in confusion as I try to figure out what's going on, eventually spotting the trace of my actions.

I have not done anything to merit saving the game. I am uncomfortable with my avatars, too numerous for me to be attached to them. I am feeling jarred by writing errors and stilted, uninteresting conversations in a game which I expected to excel at polished writing and flexibility.

I know that this is the introduction scene, the part of the game I can expect to be the most polished, the most examined by developers and testers. From here on in, the likelihood of bugs, errors and annoyances is only going to rise.

I quit the game.

I don't know whether Sepent in the Staglands goes on to deliver what it claims in terms of an open, evolving world of choice and consequence, because I have been put off attempting it again by the entirely unimmersive introduction. It feels like something I will have to steel myself to attempt again at some point, a direct contrast to the joy I usually feel at toying with the opening sections of most of its competitors for my attention.
